case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 2060 of 1971, 67, 139 and 393 of 1972

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2060 of 1971, 67, 139 and 393 of 1972 from Delhi High Court judgments dated 22nd September 1970 and 25th March 1971.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2060 of 1971, 67, 139 and 393 of 1972. From the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd September, 1970 and 25th March, 1971 of the Delhi High Court at New Delhi in Civil Writ Nos. 196 and 550 of 1970 respectively and WRIT PETITION No. 287 of 1973.

facts.text: Supreme Court disposed of the appeals on 16-8-1972.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by- PALEKAR, J.-The above appeals were disposed of by this Court on 16-8-1972.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside the seniority list prepared by the Department on 15-7-1968.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt set aside the seniority list prepared by the Department on 15-7-1968 and gave directions as to how the same was to be prepared.

facts.text: Quota rule giving 66-1/2% posts to direct recruits and 33-1/2% to promotees lapsed after 15-1-1959 due to Government's decision to promote large number of Income-tax Officers from Class II to Class I.

anchor.surface_text: The principal point which was decided in these appeals related to the validity of the quota rule and the seniority rule in their operation after 15-1-1959. This Court held that on Governments decision to Promote a large number of Income-tax Officers from Class 11 to Class 1, the quota rule which gave 66-1/2 of the posts to the direct recruits and 33-1/2 of the posts to the promoters companylapsed

facts.text: Seniority rule giving weightage of 2 to 3 years to promotees broke down with lapse of quota rule.

anchor.surface_text: and with the companylapse of that quota rule, the sonority rule which gave weighty to the promotees of 2 to 3 years also broke down-

facts.text: Supreme Court directed Government to devise a new seniority rule from 16-1-1959 in consultation with UPSC if necessary.

anchor.surface_text: Since the old seniority rule has ceased to operate by reason of the infringement of the quota rule it will be for the Government to devise, if necessary in companysultation with the Union Public Service Commission, a just and fair seniority rule as between the direct recruits and the promotees for being given effect to from 16-1-1959.

facts.text: Seniority list from 1951 to 15-1-1959 to be prepared per quota rule of 1951 r/w seniority rule.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly sneaking the seniority list from 1951 to 15-1-1959 will be prepared in accordance with the quota rule of 1951 r w the seniority rule 1 f  iii .

facts.text: Respondents directed to prepare fresh seniority list and file in court within six months.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents namely the Union of India, the Ministry of Finance and the Central Board of Direct Taxes are, therefore, directed to prepare a fresh seniority list and file it in companyrt. ... We are, therefore, of the view that the respondents charged with the preparation of the fresh list shall prepare it and file it in companyrt within six months from the date of this order.

facts.text: On February 9, 1973, President made Income-tax Officers (Class I) Service (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1973 effective from 16-1-1959.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly on February 9, 1973 the President under the proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution made rules called the Income-tax Officers  Class I  Service  Regulation of Seniority  Rules, 1973 to companye into force from 16-1-1959.

facts.text: New seniority rule (Rule 3): seniority among promotees by order of selection, direct recruits by merit order, relative seniority 1:1 ratio per roster: promotee, direct, promotee, direct recruits etc.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 which is referred to hereinafter as the new seniority rule is as follows 3, Seniority of officers-The seniority of the Income-tax Officers in the Class I service shall be regulated as from the date of companymencement of these rules in accordance with the provisions hereinafter companytained namely the seniority among the promotees inter se shall be determined in the order of selection for such promotion ... and the relative seniority among the promotees and the direct recruits hall be in the ratio of 1 1 and the same shall be so determined and regulated in accordance with a roster maintained for the purpose, which shall follow the following sequence, namely -  a  promotee  b  direct recruit  c  promotee  d  direct recruits and so on.

facts.text: Department prepared new seniority list per directions and filed in court on February 15, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: Having framed the above rule to regulate the seniority of the officers, in supersession of any other rule which was in force for the time being, the department prepared the seniority list in accordance with the directions given in the judgment and filed it in companyrt on February 15, 1973.

facts.text: Fixation of seniority till 15-1-1959 follows directions and is not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the directions given in the judgment have been followed with regard to the fixation of seniority till 15-1-1959.

facts.text: If new seniority rule valid, seniority list down to serial No. 1717 is correct, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is also number disputed that if the new seniority rule referred to above is a valid rule, then the rest of the seniority list which companyes down to serial No. 1717 is also companyrect.

facts.text: 73 promotees appointed between 1956-1958 had no quota posts for absorption, became spill-overs on 16-1-1959.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore when the present seniority, list was prepared, Government had on its hands 73 promotees who, though appointed earlier between 19561958, had numberquota posts for their absorption. On 16-1- 1959 the 73 promotees, who are described as spill-overs on 16-1-1959,

facts.text: In 1950s, promotees appointed in excess of quota, regularised later when posts available.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to recall that in the 1950s there were several years when the promotees were appointed to posts which were in excess of their quota. Though the appointments were irregular when made, they were regularised in later years when posts from their quota became available for them.

facts.text: Seniority list serial 1-485: prior to 16-1-1959 per old quota rule.

anchor.surface_text: The seniority list from serial No. 1 to serial No. 485 relating to the period prior to 16-1-1959 i.e. to say, from 1951 onwards, has been prepared in accordance with the quota rule r w the seniority rule which prevailed till then.

facts.text: Serial Nos. 486 to 1717: from 16-1-1959 per new rule, alternate promotee and direct recruit.

anchor.surface_text: Serial Nos. 486 to 1717 relate to officers who have to be accommodated from 16-1-1959 in accordance with the new seniority rule. Since under rule 3 iii  the promotee must companye first and then the direct recruit, serial No. 486 goes to a promotes and serial No. 487 goes to a direct recruit and so on.

facts.text: All promotees below serial No. 485 are spill-overs of 16-1-1959 or later promotees.

anchor.surface_text: All the promotees who companye below serial No. 485 are either out of the spillovers of 16-1-1959 or those who have been appointed by promotion later.

facts.text: Court directed spill-overs to be absorbed on priority basis.

anchor.surface_text: Since it was anticipated that there would be a spillover like this, the department had been directed that these officers must be absorbed on a priority basis.

facts.text: New seniority list covers all officers including spill-overs from 16-1-1959 onwards.

anchor.surface_text: The Government, therefore prepared a new seniority list number only as regards the officers who were absorbed in the service before 15-1-1959, but all officers, including these spill- overs, appointed after 15-1-1959.

facts.text: Promotees challenge new rule as unjust, unfair, violative of Article 16.

anchor.surface_text: The principal objection is to the validity of the new rule. It is challenged number only as unjust and unfair but also as violative of the promotees fundamental right under Article 16 of the Constitution.

facts.text: 214 officers promoted from 1959 to 1962 after upgrading equal number of Class II posts.

anchor.surface_text: The 214 officers also who were promoted from 1959 to 1962 after upgrading an equal number of class 11 posts companyld number possibly claim better treatment than the 73 spill-overs who were their seniors.

facts.text: No promotions in 1963, 1965, 1967-1970 to absorb earlier promotees.

anchor.surface_text: the department decided number to make any promotions in the years 1963, 1965 and 1967 to 1970 so that the officers who had been already promoted companyld be absorbed in their quota.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 as correct.

anchor.surface_text: Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions given by this Court in its judgment dated 16-8-1972, we accept it as the companyrect seniority list.

facts.text: Government suggested package deal in letter dated 17-2-1960 to UPSC: 50-50 quota, promotees senior to direct recruits of same year.

anchor.surface_text: A second suggestion was the one put forward by the Government in the letter dated 17-2-1960 to the Union Public Service Commission wherein a package deal was suggested. The seniority rule, as it stood, was to go and in its place the seniority rule should be that promoted officers in any calendar year should be senior to the direct recruits appointed that year only.

issues.text: Whether the new seniority rule (Income-tax Officers Class I Service Regulation of Seniority Rules, 1973, Rule 3) is valid?

anchor.surface_text: Having framed the above rule to regulate the seniority of the officers, in supersession of any other rule which was in force for the time being, the department prepared the seniority list in accordance with the directions given in the judgment and filed it in court on February 15, 1973. It is not disputed that the directions given in the judgment have been followed with regard to the fixation of seniority till 15-1-1959. It is also not disputed that if the new seniority rule referred to above is a valid rule, then the rest of the seniority list which comes down to serial No. 1717 is also correct. The principal objection is to the validity of the new rule.

issues.text: Whether the new seniority rule is unjust and unfair?

anchor.surface_text: violative of the promotees fundamental right under Article 16 of the Constitution. It is necessary to recall that in the 1950s there were several years when the promotees were appointed to posts which were in excess of their quota.

issues.text: Whether the new seniority rule is violative of the promotees' fundamental right under Article 16 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: violative of the promotees fundamental right under Article 16 of the Constitution. It is necessary to recall that in the 1950s there were several years when the promotees were appointed to posts which were in excess of their quota.

issues.text: Whether the 73 spillover promotees should be shown in the seniority list as having been appointed on 16-1-1959 in a block ahead of direct recruits?

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the 73 spillover promotees of 16-1-1959 is that since this Court had directed that they should be absorbed on a priority basis, all of them should have been shown in the seniority list as having been appointed on 16-1-1959 in a block and thereafter the direct recruits for that year should have been shown.

issues.text: Whether at least 10 out of the 73 spill-over promotees should have been accommodated prior to 16-1-1959 as a slight deviation from the quota rule?

anchor.surface_text: It was faintly argued that at least 10 out of these 73 spill-overs should have been accommodated in the period prior to 16-1-1959 on the ground that this would have amounted, in the language of the judgment, to a slight deviation from the quota rule.

issues.text: Whether promotees (spill-overs and subsequent) must be deemed validly appointed under Rule 4 of the ITO Class I Grade II Recruitment Rules 1945 post quota lapse, entitling them to seniority by date of appointment without retrospective alteration violative of Article 16?

anchor.surface_text: deemed to have been validly appointed in accordance with rule 4 of the income-tax Officers Class 1 Grade II Service Recruitment Rules, 1945, and since there remained in existence no seniority or quota rule determining their seniority vis-a-vis. the direct recruits, their natural seniority of earlier appointment cannot retrospectively be altered to their detriment, and to do so would be violative of Article 16

issues.text: Whether the new seniority rule framed by the Government is just and fair as directed by the Court?

anchor.surface_text: the new seniority rule as violative of Article 16. The argument based on Article 16 It was next contended on behalf of the promotees that this Court had directed that the rule to be framed by the Government should, be just and fair but in their submission, it was not so.

anchor.surface_text: the Government came to an arbitrary or unreasonable decision. It was contended on behalf of the promotees that a fairer way would have been to fix seniority in accordance with the dates of appointment...

arguments.claim: Post quota lapse, promotees deemed validly appointed under Rule 4 of ITO Recruitment Rules 1945 with natural seniority by appointment date which cannot be retrospectively altered (violates Article 16)

anchor.surface_text: it was next contended that as the quota rule expired on 16-1-1959, the promotees who comprised this spill-over as also those who were promoted thereafter must be deemed to have been validly appointed in accordance with rule 4 of the income-tax Officers Class 1 Grade II Service Recruitment Rules, 1945, and since there remained in existence no seniority or quota rule determining their seniority vis-a-vis. the direct recruits, their natural seniority of earlier appointment cannot retrospectively be altered to their detriment, and to do so would be violative of Article 16 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Infirmity continued post lapse without new allocation; ad hoc appointments no vested seniority; service constitution requires quota/seniority rules

arguments.claim: New rule not just and fair as directed; should give weightage to promotees considering age, experience, diminished higher promotion chances

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended on behalf of the promotees that this Court had directed that the rule to be framed by the Government should, be just and fair but in their submission, it was not so. The promotees contended that having regard to their age at the time of promotion, their experience, and their diminished chances of promotions to grades higher than those of the Assistant Commissioners, Govt. ought to have given them due weightage in the matter of seniority and since this was not done the new seniority rule was neither just nor fair.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: will survive numberserious ground for companyplaint, because all those in the lists will be appointed in the companyrse of the year and will number fa

arguments.court_reasoning: Govt policy decision after considering interests, expansion needs, experience; 50% quota gain for promotees offsets no weightage

arguments.claim: Government's choice of 1:1 roster arbitrary/unreasonable; fairer to fix seniority by dates of appointment with spill-overs on 16-1-1959

anchor.surface_text: Detailed reasons have been given in the affidavit why the three alternatives were rejected in favour of the last alternative and on a consideration of the same, we do not think that the Government came to an arbitrary or unreasonable decision. It was contended on behalf of the promotees that a fairer way would have been to fix seniority in accordance with the dates of appointment...

arguments.court_reasoning: First alternative rejected to avoid blockages from en bloc appointments disadvantaging promotions; detailed affidavit reasons

arguments.claim: 50% quota for promotees erodes direct recruits' interests unduly; unusual proportion, should be lower as in other services
arguments.court_reasoning: Govt/PSC policy on ratios considering expansion, experience needs; direct recruits no standing to complain on policy

arguments.claim: Old quota and seniority rules lapsed on 16-1-1959 requiring new rule from that date

anchor.surface_text: The court set aside the seniority list prepared by the Department on 15-7-1968 and gave directions as to how the same was to be prepared. The principal point which was decided in these appeals related to the validity of the quota rule and the seniority rule in their operation after 15-1-1959. This Court held that on Governments decision to Promote a large number of Income-tax Officers from Class 11 to Class 1, the quota rule which gave 66-1/2 of the posts to the direct recruits and 33-1/2 of the posts to the promotees lapsed and with the lapse of that quota rule, the seniority rule which gave weightage to the promotees of 2 to 3 years also broke down.

arguments.claim: New seniority rule framed under Art 309 proviso valid and effective from 16-1-1959; seniority list per it correct

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly on February 9, 1973 the President under the proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution made rules called the Income-tax Officers Class I Service Regulation of Seniority Rules, 1973 to come into force from 16-1-1959. ... It is also not disputed that if the new seniority rule referred to above is a valid rule, then the rest of the seniority list which comes down to serial No. 1717 is also correct.

arguments.claim: Ad hoc/officiating promotee appointments carry no vested seniority right; subject to final integrating rule

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that all the promotees from 16-1-1959 onwards had been appointed on an officiating or ad hoc basis with notice that the question of their seniority was still undecided, the appointments carried their own infirmity as irregular appointments, and hence in the absence of clear allocation of posts, they could hardly lay claim to any seniority and object that their natural seniority had undergone an unwarranted change in violation of Article 16.

arguments.claim: New rule not violative of Art 16; adjustment of inter se seniority for integration not discrimination

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we dont see on what grounds the promotees before us can challenge the new seniority rule as violative of Article 16. The argument based on Article 16 proceeded on the assumption that the spill-over promotees of 16-1-1959 and the officers promoted thereafter were entitled to claim seniority from the date of their appointment.

arguments.claim: Precedents like Mervyn Coutinho distinguished: no prior integration without seniority rule here

anchor.surface_text: The cases on which reliance was placed on behalf of the promotees are quite inapplicable. In Mervyn Coutinho Ors. Collector of Customs, Bombay Ors the point was whether Appraisers promoted to the grade of Principal Appraisers could be discriminated... once officers from two sources came into one integrated grade, viz. the grade of Appraisers, their seniority in the grade of Principal Appraisers was to be governed by their length of service.

arguments.claim: New rule just/fair: Govt considered 4 alternatives, chose 1:1 roster reasonably to avoid blockages

anchor.surface_text: The Government considered all these four alternatives and having seen the inconvenience and disadvantages in following the first three alternatives decided in favour of the fourth alternative as fair and just. Detailed reasons have been given in the affidavit why the three alternatives were rejected... we do not think that the Government came to an arbitrary or unreasonable decision.

arguments.claim: Seniority list Annexure B correct per directions; accept as final

anchor.surface_text: Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions given by this Court in its judgment dated 16-8-1972, we accept it as the correct seniority list.

holdings.text: The seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is the correct seniority list.

anchor.surface_text: Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions given by this Court in its judgment dated 16-8-1972, we accept it as the correct seniority list.

holdings.reasoning_summary: List prepared per previous directions and new rule; challenges to rule rejected.

holdings.text: The new seniority rule is not violative of Article 16.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we dont see on what grounds the promotees before us can challenge the new seniority rule as violative of Article 16. The argument based on Article 16 proceeded on the assumption that the spill-over promotees of 16-1-1959 and the officers promoted thereafter were entitled to claim seniority from the date of their appointment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No vested right to seniority by ad hoc appointment date; adjustment for cadre integration not discriminatory.

holdings.text: The new seniority rule framed by the Government is just and fair.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Government considered alternatives, policy needs for expansion/experience; 50% quota gain for promotees; avoids blockages.

holdings.text: The Government did not come to an arbitrary or unreasonable decision in choosing the 1:1 roster.

anchor.surface_text: Detailed reasons have been given in the affidavit why the three alternatives were rejected in favour of the last alternative and on a consideration of the same, we do not think that the Government came to an arbitrary or unreasonable decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected other alternatives due to disadvantages like en bloc blockages; affidavit details justify choice.

holdings.text: The 73 spillover promotees are governed by the new seniority rule and not placed in a block on 16-1-1959 ahead of direct recruits.

anchor.surface_text: It was true that this Court had directed that these promotees should be absorbed on a priority basis. That only meant that their position as senior should not be prejudiced by any possible claim by later promotees... They were to be governed by a rule which covered all those who came or were deemed to have come into the cadre after 15-1-1959.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Priority absorption not overriding new rule; applies to all post-1959 entrants equally.

holdings.text: The 73 spill-overs cannot be accommodated prior to 16-1-1959 as a deviation from quota rule.

anchor.surface_text: That observation, however, applied to a situation when the Government deliberately made an appointment in a stray post... Government went on making appointments knowing that the promotees had no posts out of their quota and it only hoped to regularize them when posts were available.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deviation for stray appointments only, not mass excess hoping regularization.

holdings.text: Promotees post quota lapse not deemed validly appointed with natural seniority by date; infirmity continues without new rule.

anchor.surface_text: This submission does not bear scrutiny. When the 73 spill-over appointments had been made, there were no allocated posts to which the appointments could have been validly made... The infirmity in the appointments continued on 16-1-1959 and that infirmity could not be overcome except by a new rule which made some posts available.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quota lapse does not auto-regularize irregular appointments; service constitution requires allocation rules.

holdings.text: 50% quota for promotees is acceptable; no undue erosion of direct recruits' interests.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy decision for service needs; direct recruits no locus on quota ratios.

holdings.text: Ad hoc and officiating appointments of promotees confer no vested right to seniority by date of appointment.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that all the promotees from 16-1-1959 onwards had been appointed on an officiating or ad hoc basis with notice that the question of their seniority was still undecided, the appointments carried their own infirmity as irregular appointments, and hence in the absence of clear allocation of posts, they could hardly lay claim to any seniority...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointments irregular, notice given seniority undecided; subject to final integrating rule.

holdings.text: Precedents like Mervyn Coutinho inapplicable as no prior integrated cadre without seniority rule here.

anchor.surface_text: The cases on which reliance was placed on behalf of the promotees are quite inapplicable. In Mervyn Coutinho Ors... once officers from two sources came into one integrated grade... their seniority in the grade of Principal Appraisers was to be governed by their length of service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished: requires prior integration; here necessary to fix inter se for integration.

anchor.surface_text: 1967  2  S.C.R. 703 at 718 . This was soon realised and hence in an endeavour to maintain the quota ratio the department decided not to make any promotions in the years 1963, 1965 and 1967 to 1970 so that the officers who had been already promoted could be absorbed in their quota.

precedents.cited_proposition: there could be no valid appointments outside the quota

precedents.citation: Mervyn Coutinho Ors. Collector of Customs, Bombay Ors 1

anchor.surface_text: In Mervyn Coutinho Ors. Collector of Customs, Bombay Ors 1  the point was whether Appraisers promoted to the grade of Principal Appraisers could be discriminated in the matter of seniority in the grade of Principal Appraisers on the ground that they had entered the grade of Appraisers as either promotees or direct recruits.

precedents.case_name: Mervyn Coutinho v. Collector of Customs, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: once officers from two sources came into one integrated grade, their seniority in the higher grade is governed by length of service in that grade and birth marks cannot be carried forward
precedents.cited_holding: all Appraisers lost their birth marks after integration and they could not be revived after promotion to higher grade

anchor.surface_text: In Roshan Lal v.  1  1966 3 S.C.R. 600. Union of India, 1  the decision in Marvyn Coutinhos case referred to, above was relied upon and reaffirmed. The case does not shed any light on the question with which we are concerned.

precedents.case_name: Roshan Lal v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: reaffirmed the principle in Mervyn Coutinho's case regarding integration of promotees and direct recruits

precedents.citation: S. M. Pandit and Anr. v. State of Gujarat.  2

anchor.surface_text: Similar is the case in S. M. Pandit and Anr. v. State of Gujarat.  2  In this case Mamlatdars were recruited from two sources-directly and by promotion. They had the same designation, same pay scales, same functions and their posts were also interchangeable.

precedents.case_name: S. M. Pandit v. State of Gujarat
precedents.cited_proposition: Government cannot discriminate between direct recruits and promotees (Mamlatdars) in matter of further promotion to Deputy Collector

anchor.surface_text: Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions given by this Court in its judgment dated 16-8-1972, we accept it as the correct seniority list.

The argument regarding no vested seniority from ad hoc/officiating appointments addresses the issue of seniority placement for spillover promotees.

anchor.surface_text: Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions given by this Court in its judgment dated 16-8-1972, we accept it as the correct seniority list.

In these circumstances we dont see on what grounds the promotees before us can challenge the new seniority rule as violative of Article 16. The argument based on Article 16 proceeded on the assumption that the spill-over promotees of 16-1-1959 and the officers promoted thereafter were entitled to claim seniority from the date of their appointment.
Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions given by this Court in its judgment dated 16-8-1972, we accept it as the correct seniority list.

anchor.surface_text: It was true that this Court had directed that these promotees should be absorbed on a priority basis. That only meant that their position as senior should not be prejudiced by any possible claim by later promotees... They were to be governed by a rule which covered all those who came or were deemed to have come into the cadre after 15-1-1959.
Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions given by this Court in its judgment dated 16-8-1972, we accept it as the correct seniority list.

anchor.surface_text: That observation, however, applied to a situation when the Government deliberately made an appointment in a stray post... Government went on making appointments knowing that the promotees had no posts out of their quota and it only hoped to regularize them when posts were available.
Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions given by this Court in its judgment dated 16-8-1972, we accept it as the correct seniority list.

anchor.surface_text: This submission does not bear scrutiny. When the 73 spill-over appointments had been made, there were no allocated posts to which the appointments could have been validly made... The infirmity in the appointments continued on 16-1-1959 and that infirmity could not be overcome except by a new rule which made some posts available.
Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions given by this Court in its judgment dated 16-8-1972, we accept it as the correct seniority list.
